bibl.title: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Ignacio Alvare to Philip Showalter Hench, July 18, 1940

div1.p: Alvare explains circumstances of the photograph he made of the supposed site of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Ignacio Alvare to Philip Showalter Hench, July 18, 1940 (See Spanish original.)
div1.opener:
Dr. Ignacio Alvare
9 No. 304
Vedado, Havana, Cuba
July 18, 1940
Dr. P. S. Hench
Rochester, Minnesota
My esteemed Doctor:
div1.p:
I received your kind letter of June 24 and I ask your
foregiveness because of the delay in answering it. This has been
due to the fact that I have been ill.

In regard to the business that you refer to in your letter,
I inform you that I was interning in the Military Hospital in the
years 1923 to 1926, and in this last year, I took the photograph
of which you know. That location was pointed at by the people as
the place where the Camp Lazear was built, and the little house was
supposed to be the remains of it; this was vox populi, without my
having any personal proof of it. As historical data it occurred
to me to take the photograph and present a copy of it to Dr. Recio,
who was one of my favorite teachers.

The looks of the little house was rather shabby, but it
must be realized that much time had gone by between its construction
and 1926, and also that people from the lower classes had been using
it and had failed to make the necessary repairs. In regard to the
tree, I don't know whether it is still in evidence, but I must point
out the fact that I took that photograph in May, 1926, and in October
of the same year, a cyclone went through that region and the house
and the tree may have disappeared.

This is all I have to inform you, and it is a pleasure to
have answered your letter.
div1.closer: Yours truly, (Signed) Dr. Ignacio Alvare (Translated by Dr. Sacasa)
